Fiction
THE INDWELLING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) The seventh volume in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist. (+)
CRADLE AND ALL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) A former nun turned private eye works on a case involving two virgins who become pregnant.
*HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a witchcraft school.
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is threatened.
EASY PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $25.95.) The homicide detective Lucas Davenport investigates the strangulation of a famous model.
THE BRETHREN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Three former judges, doing time at a federal prison in Florida, concoct a mail scam that goes awry.
BEFORE I SAY GOOD-BYE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A woman with ESP searches for the truth behind the death of her husband.
*THE BLUEST EYE, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $15.) The story of an 11-year-old black girl -- pregnant by her father -- who prays for her eyes to turn blue.
THE SEARCH, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $24.95.) A woman and her golden retriever, part of a K-9 rescue team, are forced to participate in a deadly mission.
*OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $17.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.

THE VINEYARD, by Barbara Delinsky. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) When the owner of a vineyard decides to write a memoir, intended for her children, she enlists the help of a woman who is unprepared for what is to follow.
THE EMPTY CHAIR, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Forensic specialists pursue a disturbed teenage boy who abducted two young women.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for witchcraft.
WHITE TEETH, by Zadie Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A chronicle of two families, encompassing 150 years, that revolves around an Englishman and his friendship with a Bengali Muslim from Bangladesh.
*ANIL'S GHOST, by Michael Ondaatje. (Knopf, $25.) A Sri Lankan woman who studied medicine abroad returns to examine the victims of her country's terror.

Nonfiction
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of one of them.

IN THE HEART OF THE SEA, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $24.95.) An account of the whaleship Essex, whose disastrous fate in the early 19th century would later serve as inspiration for Herman Melville.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A collection of autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
NO SUCH THING AS A BAD DAY, by Hamilton Jordan. (Longstreet, $22.) A memoir by Jimmy Carter's chief of staff, who has survived three bouts with cancer.
IN A SUNBURNED COUNTRY, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) The author of ''A Walk in the Woods'' reports on his travels through Australia.
FROM DAWN TO DECADENCE, by Jacques Barzun. (HarperCollins, $36.) A survey of 500 years of Western cultural life, from 1500 to the present.
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
*PAYNE STEWART, by Tracey Stewart with Ken Abraham. (Broadman & Holman, $24.99.) A biography of the golfer who died in a plane crash in 1999, by his widow. (+)

DUTY, by Bob Greene. (Morrow, $25.) The columnist remembers his father, who was a soldier in World War II, and tells the story of Paul Tibbets, who piloted the plane that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima.
THE CAMINO, by Shirley MacLaine. (Pocket, $24.95.) A ''journey of the spirit'' takes the actress from present-day Spain through past lives to the origin of the universe.
THE GREATEST GENERATION SPEAKs, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $19.95.) What the people who fought in World War II confided in letters to the author.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
*FAIR BALL, by Bob Costas. (Broadway, $21.95.) The sportscaster's critique of major league baseball and his proposals for improving the game.

And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

BEE SEASON, by Myla Goldberg. (Doubleday, $22.95.) An intelligent, dispassionate first novel that constructs and deconstructs a somewhat off-center Jewish family whose lives change when a hitherto ordinary fifth-grade daughter turns out to be an all-American spelling bee champ.

BOSIE: A Biography of Lord Alfred Douglas, by Douglas Murray. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion, $27.50.) A remarkable effort to see whole and uncaricatured the beautiful rich boy who became infamous for his betrayal of Oscar Wilde. The author, it is worth knowing, is 20 years old.

THE GRAVITY OF SUNLIGHT, by Rosa Shand. (Soho, $24.) An acutely sensuous first novel whose deft plotting follows the precarious marriage of two Americans living in Uganda toward 1971 and the seizure of power by the terrifying Idi Amin; their real love affair is with the country itself.

GROUCHO: The Life and Times of Julius Henry Marx, by Stefan Kanfer. (Knopf, $30.) A vivid, cleanly written biography of the acerbic vaudeville clown who became, at last, the mean man he had long pretended to be.

JIM THE BOY, by Tony Earley. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) A first novel, a coming-of-age novel, a Southern novel -- and yet no monsters, no parental abuse, erotic turmoil or domestic dysfunction! This clear, balanced, understated book makes growing up seem somehow possible.

KING DAVID: A Biography, by Steven L. McKenzie. (Oxford University, $25.) The texts -- nothing is known of David outside the Hebrew Bible -- are sharply cross-examined by a scholar to see how the story stands up after 3,000 years.

MOTHERHOOD MADE A MAN OUT OF ME, by Karen Karbo. (Bloomsbury, $23.95.) Motherhood is the lead character in this peevishly hilarious novel that contains two plots about two women, close friends but in circumstances very unlike, except both are having babies, or have had or will.

PAPAL SIN: Structures of Deceit, by Garry Wills. (Doubleday, $25.) An argument, angry and sorrowful, by a Roman Catholic who thinks the concentration of authority in the pope has led to ever more lamentable cover-ups of mistakes and assertions of things that are not so.

PLOWING THE DARK, by Richard Powers. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) An awfully smart novel of brute juxtaposition that crosscuts between two screening rooms of the mind: a cell in Beirut where an American hostage is held and a virtual-reality lab in Seattle.

THE YEAR OF JUBILO: A Novel of the Civil War, by Howard Bahr. (Holt, $25.) Time and place are skillfully evoked while large, sweeping, cinematic events stay in the sights of this tale of the war's aftermath in little, ruined Cumberland, Miss.
